subline: Inpatient treatment can start in just 24 hours.
title: What is Inpatient Treatment?
body: For some people, a highly structured treatment setting can make all the difference when it comes to getting sober and staying that way. In inpatient (or residential) treatment, you’ll live full-time at one of our comfortable treatment centers for a few weeks. You’ll attend scheduled groups and therapy sessions most of the day and have limited outside contact at first. You’ll bring very little with you; our goal is to remove triggers and stressors of daily life as much as possible so that you can focus completely on your recovery. And when you’re ready to return to “regular life,” we’ll make sure you have every support in place for continued sobriety success.

heroTitle: Worried about addiction treatment and insurance?
subline: Inpatient treatment can start in just 24 hours.
title: Will my insurance cover addiction treatment?
body: Most insurance companies can cover up to 100% of the cost of addiction treatment. We’ll work with your providers and within your budget to find the best option for you. We also partner with American Healthcare Lending and Care Credit to to match people with the financial assistance that fits best with their unique situation.

subline: Medical Detox can start in just 24 hours.
title: What is Medical Detox?
body: Even when you’ve made up your mind to focus on sobriety and healing, your body still needs to process the leftover drugs and alcohol in its system. This process can involve intense symptoms that require constant, compassionate clinical care. In our Medical Detox program, you’ll be monitored around the clock by our medical team to ensure safe, healthy withdrawal as your body begins to heal from chemical dependency.

subline: Outpatient Treatment can start in just 24 hours.
title: What is Outpatient Treatment?
body: An Intensive Outpatient addiction treatment program is a flexible option designed to meet you wherever you are in your recovery journey. Some people use outpatient programs to get serious addiction treatment while still keeping up with home, work and family obligations; others use it as a “step-down” from residential or inpatient treatment as they learn to incorporate sobriety into real life.
